From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] Self-adaptive Mutation Rates, Novelty Search and CMA-ES
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=i-ZpHlAwrYhY91n8GAJgUIFNsddGa4LnOTxRYXqEPo1SBcBgLOpH
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune


--Apple-Mail=_A9FA3CE4-8256-4607-B898-5D822CB794A4
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello Joel and Vassilis,

I=92ll respond in this thread since it is focused=
 on the issue of self-adatptive mutation rates and novelty search. I=92ll f=
irst respond to Vassilis then Joel=92s original comments. Please see below.=
 
 
> Self-adaptive mutation rates are a terrible idea:
> Jeff, thanks for =
pointing this out. That is an interesting paper! To be honest I haven't rea=
d it before; so, you are saying that self-adaptive mutation rates can be mo=
re effective on smoother fitness landscapes, correct?
> 
> Novelty Search:
=
> Joel, could novelty search be seen as a way of creating a smoother fitnes=
s landscape? If yes, then based on what you said, is this the reason why se=
lf-adaptive mutation rates work better when coupled with novelty search?
> =


I agree with you. Self-adaptive mutation rates work fine on smooth landsc=
apes. Of course, landscapes on any interesting, non-trivial problem are rug=
ged, so that means that generally self-adaptive mutation rates are a very b=
ad idea. Novelty search, however, makes the conversation more complex. I ag=
ree with you that NS smoothes out landscapes, making self-adaptive mutation=
 rates far less pathological. That said, I=92m not yet sure that self-adapt=
ive mutation rates are actually a good idea with Novelty Search (see below)=
. 

> 
> I believe the idea of self-adaptive mutation rates formed the basi=
s for more advanced evolution strategies such as CMA-ES. I am not trying to=
 defend CMA-ES here, which I agree with Jeff that it works differently than=
 the basic approach of encoding the mutation rates in the genotype. However=
, I am wondering whether a combination of novelty search with CMA-ES would =
be a good approach in speeding up the search for novel behaviours.
> 
> Of =
course, I can see some disadvantages of CMA-ES, an example being that the g=
enotype is a vector of real numbers with a fixed size... What do you think?=

> 

I don=92t think what makes CMA-ES effective has anything to do with se=
lf-adaptive mutation rates. I think that it=92s advantage is in learning co=
rrelations. But, as far as I know, it=92s still forced to mutate genomes ac=
cording to those correlations. I must admit I don=92t know the CMA_ES liter=
ature at all, but my guess is that if you tried CMA-ES with and without a m=
utation rate on the genome, you=92d get the same result I report in my pape=
r: as long as the landscape is rugged (i.e. the problem is non-trivial), ev=
olution will floor mutation rates and the result will underperform the best=
, fixed mutation rate. Anyone know the literature enough to know if I=92m r=
ight? Or anyone care to give it a try?

Regarding Joel=92s claim that wheth=
er self-adaptation is a good idea depends on whether fitness is based on an=
 objective or NS:

I love Joel and Ken=92s paper looking into whether self-=
adaptative mutation rates (SAMR) are a better idea with NS. As I said above=
, it makes sense that SAMR would be less bad with NS, because NS smooths ou=
t landscapes and eliminates peaks, but is it actually a *good* idea instead=
 of just being less bad? On that question I am still agnostic pending furth=
er research. 

One reason is because of "novelty plateaus=94, a concept my =
students and I introduce in our last, not-yet-announced GECCO paper. Novelt=
y plateaus exist when, during novelty search, mutating the current populati=
on does not immediately produce new behaviors. For example, once the low-ha=
nging fruit is consumed, it might take 5 specific mutations to produce a ne=
w behavior (assume that all intermediate mutations have no effect on behavi=
or). In that case, NS cannot reward those stepping stones to the new behavi=
or, and thus there is no incentive to have a high mutation rate. Since most=
 mutations break things (producing the very un-novel behavior of doing litt=
le or nothing), I hypothesize that having a high mutation rate will be sele=
cted against when on such a novelty plateau. In other words, think of the l=
ong, flat lines of fitness you (Joel) mentioned: We hypothesize that those =
long-flat lines also exist in terms of generating new behaviors and, if we'=
re right, I think there would be a pressure to lower mutation rates during =
such periods, even though keeping the mutation rate high is exactly what yo=
u need to cross the plateau. Of course, a lot of this is speculation, and I=
 think a paper on this subject would be very interesting and worthwhile for=
 the community.

Now let me argue against myself, since I=92m thinking thro=
ugh these issues by writing about them in this thread! While I can imagine =
that novelty plateaus exist, for the specific purposes of this conversation=
 on mutation rates, I can=92t figure out if they would actually cause selec=
tion for lower mutation rates, because even if you are not generating not-y=
et-seen-before behaviors, you can be generating non-new behaviors in differ=
ent regions of density in the archive=85meaning that you may truly always b=
e on the side of a hill and not on a neutral plateau. What do y=92all think=
?

An additional reason I=92m not yet ready to commit to the claim that SAM=
R is a good idea with NS is because your paper didn=92t show that SAMR did =
optimize mutation rates for long-term adaptation. You did not sweep over th=
e range of fixed mutation rates and show that SAMR found those optimal rate=
s, or outperformed them. Instead, you showed that it performed better than =
the parameters you had for the initial experiment. 

An final reason I=92m =
agnostic (so far) on the issue of whether SAMR helps with NS is because the=
 evidence in your paper, while very interesting, was also not overly strong=
 or consistent. I hope you won=92t be offended and think I=92m critical of =
you and Ken or the work. You may be right that SAMR+NS works, and it would =
be fascinating if you are, but I would just like to see larger effect sizes=
, lower p-values, and more consistency across domains before taking the cla=
im =93SAMR works with NS=94 to the bank. Please see below for some of my sp=
ecific reasons for this claim. 

1. I don=92t see self-adaptive mutation ra=
tes helping a lot in your results: in some cases SAMR improved evolvability=
 significantly, but not in all, and in the cases where the difference is si=
gnificant, the effect size is very small and the variance and associated p-=
value are high. The same is true for performance, where self-adaptation onl=
y helped in one domain, not all, and the difference was a jump from ~5% to =
~10% (a doubling, which is rather impressive, but with a p-value of only < =
0.05). I hope I didn=92t get any of these details wrong. I apologize if I d=
id.  

Personally I=92d prefer more tests before I really commit to this co=
nclusion and start drawing inferences from it. To repeat, I hope you don=92=
t mind that I point out that I=92d prefer more experiments and on more prob=
lems before fully committing to the view that self-adaptation helps with no=
velty search. As I said, I do think the result is probably right, as self-a=
daptation works well on smooth fitness landscapes, and NS does eliminate pe=
aks and smooth landscapes. Moreover, I think it was an extremely clever and=
 interesting question to ask and issue to raise: I=92m a big fan of the pap=
er, but I=92d still love to see follow-up studies on it because the result =
is fascinating, but so far the evidence is not as strong as it could be. 

=
2. You show that Eibd* (=93evolvability as defined as producing immediate b=
ehavioral diversity=94) is better for NS with self-adaptation, but
	a. The =
real proof is if these organisms actually evolve better in a new environmen=
t. It would be great to see those data. You have provided some evidence for=
 improved long-term evolvability since performance was higher, but again th=
at was only in one of the domains, and the difference was not huge. 
	b. Di=
d you look at what happened to the mutation rates? They may have still gone=
 down, which could produce more Eibd, but at the cost of Elt* (Evolvability=
 over the Long Term). 

3. You report that "Initial experiments revealed th=
at evolving a single mutation power and rate for each entire genome is too =
coarse.=94 That suggests that the effect may not be that robust, and may be=
 hard to take advantage of in practice. I also noted that in the treatment =
that ultimately worked, you took an intermediate route of different mutatio=
n rates for different connections, but not one set of mutation rates per-co=
nnection. Out of curiosity, did you also try that and find it didn=92t work=
? 

Overall, I do think that how bad self-adaptive mutation rates are depen=
ds on the ruggedness of landscapes, and NS makes them less bad because it s=
mooths landscapes. However, I consider the question of whether SAMR are ben=
eficial with NS to be a fascinating, open question that you have provided s=
ome evidence for, but that we=92d all benefit from seeing a lot more resear=
ch into. 

Best,
Jeff

*I=92m making these up as I go along!
--Apple-Mail=_A9FA3CE4-8256-4607-B898-5D822CB794A4

n objective or NS:</div><div><br></div><div>I love Joel and Ken=92s paper l=
ooking into whether self-adaptative mutation rates (SAMR) are a better idea=

ll agnostic pending further research. </div><div><br></div><div>One re=

gs (producing the very un-novel behavior of doing little or nothing), I hyp=
othesize that having a high mutation rate will be selected against when on =
such a novelty plateau. In other words, think of the long, flat lines of fi=
tness you (Joel) mentioned: We hypothesize that those long-flat lines also =

re would be a pressure to lower mutation rates during such periods, even th=
ough keeping the mutation rate high is exactly what you need to cross the p=

s subject would be very interesting and worthwhile for the community.</div>=

hrough these issues by writing about them in this thread! While I can imagi=
ne that novelty plateaus exist, for the specific purposes of this conversat=
ion on mutation rates, I can=92t figure out if they would actually cause se=
lection for lower mutation rates, because even if you are not generating no=
t-yet-seen-before behaviors, you can be generating non-new behaviors in dif=
ferent regions of density in the archive=85meaning that you may truly alway=
s be on the side of a hill and not on a neutral plateau. What do y=92all th=
ink?</div><div><br></div><div>An additional reason I=92m not yet ready to c=

aper, while very interesting, was also not overly strong or consistent. I h=

ou are, but I would just like to see larger effect sizes, lower p-values, a=

utation rates helping a lot in your results: in some cases SAMR improved ev=
olvability significantly, but not in all, and in the cases where the differ=
ence is significant, the effect size is very small and the variance and ass=

tation only helped in one domain, not all, and the difference was a jump fr=
om ~5% to ~10% (a doubling, which is rather impressive, but with a p-value =
of only < 0.05). I hope I didn=92t get any of these details wrong. I apo=
logize if I did.  <div><br></div><div>Personally I=92d prefer more tes=
ts before I really commit to this conclusion and start drawing inferences f=
rom it. To repeat, I hope you don=92t mind that I point out that I=92d pref=

w that self-adaptation helps with novelty search. As I said, I do think the=

ity=94) is better for NS with self-adaptation, but</div><div><span class=3D=
"Apple-tab-span" style=3D"white-space: pre;">	</span>a. The real proof is i=
f these organisms actually evolve better in a new environment. It would be =
great to see those data. You have provided some evidence for improved long-=
term evolvability since performance was higher, but again that was only in =
one of the domains, and the difference was not huge. </div><div><span =
class=3D"Apple-tab-span" style=3D"white-space: pre;">	</span>b. Did you loo=
k at what happened to the mutation rates? They may have still gone down, wh=
ich could produce more Eibd, but at the cost of Elt* (Evolvability over the=
 Long Term). </div><div><br></div><div>3. You report that "Initial exp=
eriments revealed that evolving a single mutation power and rate for each e=
ntire genome is too coarse.=94 That suggests that the effect may not be tha=
t robust, and may be hard to take advantage of in practice. I also noted th=
at in the treatment that ultimately worked, you took an intermediate route =
of different mutation rates for different connections, but not one set of m=
utation rates per-connection. Out of curiosity, did you also try that and f=
ind it didn=92t work? </div><div><br></div></div></div><div>Overall, I=

edness of landscapes, and NS makes them less bad because it smooths landsca=
pes. However, I consider the question of whether SAMR are beneficial with N=
S to be a fascinating, open question that you have provided some evidence f=
or, but that we=92d all benefit from seeing a lot more research into. =
